intro: Peucedanum sewerzowii, commonly known as the Siberian cowparsley, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and dill, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbel-like flower clusters. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with a slender stem and small, white to pale yellow flowers. Its seeds are small and dry, often used in traditional medicine for their purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. Peucedanum sewerzowii is adapted to cold climates and is often found in rocky or alpine environments.
